text:
Hey, that’s me!

What I’ve found is that nobody is going to care about a cool new language if you just show them the features. You have to actually build something cool that you couldn’t have built in MATLAB.

And it makes sense that people wouldn’t care about some new language. Experienced engineers have lived through decades of overhyped “this is what everyone is going to be using soon” pitches only to see most of that stuff die out.

If I had to break it down into steps, it would be:
1. Make something so cool they can’t resist using it.
2. Go out of your way to provide good documentation and tutorials. This includes linking to tutorials for getting Julia set up on their machines. I wrote my own tutorials for this because most people I work with have never used Git (we use Subversion for our MATLAB projects), so I had to really start from scratch there. And I had to show them how to use our local package registry. But the more information you put in tutorials, the less work you’ll have to do in helping people debug things.
3. Be prepared to be the “Julia IT person” now. Everyone is going to be coming to you to debug Julia issues because you were the person that convinced them to try the language. Set up a group chat or something (we use Microsoft Teams, so I set up a Team for that).
